However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.This is Highly Recommend, a column dedicated to what people in the food industry are obsessed with eating, drinking, and buying right now.I have a lot of cutting boards—not a huge collection but more than two and less than 10—and for the most part they’re separated into two distinct categories: functional and good-looking. My black plastic cutting boards are for everyday cooking tasks like prepping chicken breasts and chopping hearty greens. Easy to maintain and dark enough to conceal stains and scratch marks, they’re my utilitarian workhorses. Then there are my wooden cutting boards, which are pretty but high-maintenance. They require some babying to keep them supple and looking new, so I either use those as countertop decor or tuck them away unless I’m hosting.But a cutting board that’s low-maintenance and functional? I didn’t think it existed—until I got my Fredericks and Mae confetti cutting board, which has the durability of my everyday black boards, the beauty of my wooden ones, and a lot more personality than both.Fredericks & Mae Cutting Board$95 at Bon Appétit Market$100 at Coming Soon New YorkIt comes in a variety of color combos like yellow and blue, multicolored, and black and white. The busy confetti-like flecked patterns offer even more visual camouflage than my black boards do, disguising discoloration and knife scratches. That type of magic isn’t possible with wooden cutting boards, where wear and tear is usually obvious. The large (11" x 16") Fredericks and Mae cutting board is also heavy, so it doesn’t slip and slide around while I’m using it, even without a damp cloth underneath. Because it’s so gorgeous, whenever I cut anything on it—whether it be a juicy steak, seasonal galette, or a block of cheese—I just serve it straight on the cutting board. And yes, I can confirm it has the power to make any dish ready for social media prime time.Did I mention it’s made from recycled materials? Those confetti specks are leftover scraps from solid color cutting boards. It definitely has a higher price point than your average plastic board, but investing in sustainability, to me, is worth it—especially for a piece of kitchen equipment that nails both form and function.Explore Bon AppétitShoppingHighly RecommendCultureRecipes you want to make.
